title: What will annual sales of new energy vehicles (NEVs) be in China in 2019?
possible_answers: More than 1.50 million but less than 1.75 million
preds: I estimate 1,042,700 up to and including November. [1] [1] https://www.marklines.com/en/statistics/flash_sales/salesfig_china_2019#jan

https://www.google.com/amp/s/insideevs.com/news/383606/plugin-car-sales-china-october-2019/amp/
https://technode.com/2019/12/13/china-nev-november-sales/ Current total: 1.044M
With -12% YoY 'growth' for December, 1,25M can still be reached, but the last months were -34% to - 46% YoY, so I think reaching 1.25M is not likely.

Ug.  My original plan was to all in on <, and then followup after november sales reports.  And then I forgot.  Anyway - October down 45.7.  November down 43%.  
  For it to miss 1.25, sales for December must be down 47%.   Now, China has extended the EV incentives.   While boosting sales, it will prevent a rush to buy in December to get the rebates before they expire, removing immediacy.  I also wonder how much Tesla's impending (starting) sales will boost numbers, and surpress other automaker sales.  Nonetheless,  I don't see that sales dropping 47%.   But either way, I expect this to be decided by a few thousand vehicles either way.

The Chinese government has poured billions of yuan into the NEV sector and reiterated last week that electric cars remain a priority as it wants to combat pollution and reduce reliance on imported oil. Still, sales of cars running on electric motors have been falling since July as regulators reduced subsidies." https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-12-09/china-s-historic-car-slump-drags-on-as-sales-plunge-in-november

As of end-September, sales were up 20% over the first 9 months of 2018 (872K this year). However, sales are slowing significantly in recent months, being well below last year's totals for the same months, due to cancellation of government subsidies. Last year sales were 531K October to December, which would project to 1.403M if sales are the same, or 1509 in last quarter sales were up 20% over last year (per early 2019 tracking). August and September 2019 sales were down 15.8% and 34.2% over 2018, so if we project a drop, year over year, of about 20% through December, we get to about 1.14M in sales. I've chosen my probabilities accordingly.
I haven't listed my sources, but they are what a brief google search yielded from recent articles.
Hattip to @nigster for pushing me to go all in on the first bucket.

What will annual sales of new energy vehicles (NEVs) be in China in 2019?
Hattip to @riksss for an excellent analysis.

After reading reports and materials from CAAM, APCAAUTO and CADA, I found out a few facts: 
1) the Chinese vehicle market overall is experiencing a worse inventory problem than 2018, especially during 2019/07-2019/10. 
2) Chinese government's subsidy for NEVs has dropped dramatically (-50% on 2018 basis) and will be ceased by the end of 2019.
3) As a result of 1) and 2), during 2019/07-2019/10, monthly sales of NEVs in China has decreased by 4.7%,15.8%, 34.2% and 45.6% on a year-over-year basis. 
4) Now we knew annual sales of NEVs in Chinese market of 2018 is around 1.26 million and total sales during 2019/01-10 is 0.95 million. In order to catch up with 2018, Chinese NEVs market needs a total sale of 0.31 million (and a monthly average sale of 0.155 million) during 2019/11-2019/12,
5) As mentioned in 1), 2) and 3), and we knew that monthly sale of NEVs in Chinese market in 2019/10 is 0.75. If 4) truly can happen, we shall see a dramaticly increase in monthly sale during 2019/11-2019/12. Given latest inventory condition and subsidy policy will stop by the end of 2019, I gave 95% to first slot.
6) However, Chinese car dealer may need to meet their own sales goal by the end of 2019, which means they may give bigger discount on price of NEVs. Therefore, I gave 5% to second slot.
7) Btw, I saw someone mentioned that Chinese customers are waiting for Telsa Model 3 from Shanghai factory. Well, I read news that Model 3 from Shanghai factory will have lower settings compared to import version (no steering wheel heating and no PM 2.5 filter), and a slightly cheaper price (8,1000 CNY, or 1,153 USD cheaper). Therefore, I don't see how Model 3 from Shanghai factory can boost up the Chinese NEVs market heavily in next 1.5 months (if they can be delivered).
What will annual sales of new energy vehicles (NEVs) be in China in 2019? Tightening the forecast to reflect a continued slowing economy and the hoards waiting for new domestic Teslas. :-)

Sales are 872,000 for January through September. That's an average of ~97,000. Trend has been about 1/3 down over the previous year. Slim chance of it getting above 1.25. "In September, the production and sales of new energy vehicles were respectively 89,000 and 80,000 units, down 29.9% and 34.2% respectively over the same period of the previous year. Among them, the production and sales of pure electric vehicles were 74,000 and 63,000 respectively, down 26.1% and 33.1% respectively over the same period of last year; the production and sales of plug-in hybrid vehicles were 15,000 and 17,000 respectively, down from the same period of last year. 44.1% and 38.4%. From January to September, the production and sales of new energy vehicles were 888,000 and 872,000 respectively, up 20.9% and 20.8% respectively over the same period of the previous year. Among them, the production and sales of pure electric vehicles completed 717,000 and 692,000 respectively, up 29.2% and 27.8% respectively over the same period of the previous year; the production and sales of plug-in hybrid vehicles completed 170,000 and 179,000 respectively, down from the same period of last year. 5.4% and 0.8%; fuel cell vehicle production and sales respectively completed 1,315 vehicles and 1,251 vehicles, an increase of 7.7 times and 7.6 times respectively over the same period of the previous year." http://www.caam.org.cn/chn/4/cate_154/con_5226653.html

Adding up the last graph on the Clean Technica Chinese EV Report, I count 871,838.[1] And this matches with the numbers from Automotive News: "For the first three quarters, total sales of electrified vehicles in China still jumped 21 percent to roughly 872,000. The tally includes some 692,000 EVs, 179,000 plug-in hybrids and 1,251 fuel cell vehicles."[2] Aggregate sales are down to 80,000 a month from the beginning of the year, which was 100,000. Let's assume 75,000 * 3 months = 225,000 for 2019Q4. That get's us to 1.1 million. To get to the second highest level, we need another 150,000 or 50,000 a month. Possible, but I doubt it. Forecast: 1,213,000 NEV sales (way down from previous forecast of 1,976,000). Total NEV sales for Jan - Jul 2019 708k. The cumulative YoY sales are falling by about 10% per month, so if that were to continue then by the end of the year sales would be down 4% on last year making total sales about 1,206k. Alternatively averaging monthly sales for 2019 so far gives a figure of 101k sales per month. Extrapolating that for the remainder of the year gives a total of 1,213k NEV sales. I am glad I didn't overfit based on the poor May sales data because the June data shows relatively strong sales more closely aligned with pre-May sales. June sales were 80% higher than last year's June's sales [1] What was the reason? "CAAM said NEV sales rose sharply in June as buyers responded positively to incentives producers offered in anticipation of a planned rolling-back of official purchase subsidies." [2] Analysis: The average rise in 2019 so far was 63%. If we apply a 63% growth, we get ~1,887,000. I use this as the high end because China has been lowering subsidies for electric vehicles.  To get into the fourth bucket, we need a growth of just over 45%.  Since, it seems that the reason for the high sales so far could have been a front-loading of demand ahead of subsidy expiration, I am somewhat bearish on sales going forward (and therefore lower the fourth bucket from 20%). On the other hand, China is not completely removing subsidies until 2020 implying that we may see continued front-loading of demand (just less severe) ahead of the disappearance of subsidies. The remainder of the year would have to be only 13% higher than H2 2018 in order to get into the 3rd bucket.  To watch:
* the number of July will be the first indication of demand after the reduction in subsidies which was scheduled to take place end of June [3]  [1] https://www.marklines.com/en/statistics/flash_sales/salesfig_china_2019#jan
[2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-autos/china-june-auto-sales-down-96-marks-12th-month-of-decline-industry-data-idUSKCN1U50LC
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-autos-electric/china-toughens-subsidy-program-for-new-energy-vehicle-companies-idUSKCN1R80NV

- 2017 source: "China is targeting 35 million vehicle sales by 2025 and wants new energy vehicles (NEVs) to make up at least one-fifth of that total" [1] , so 7 million annual NEV sales by 2025.
- "[S]ales of new-energy vehicles (NEVs), a category including battery-powered, plug-in hybrids, and fuel-cell electric cars, kept growing despite the overall sluggish auto market. Some 1.03 million NEVs were sold in China in the first 11 months of the year, up 68% from the same period in 2017, according to CAAM data." [2] "In [all of] 2018, 1.26 million units of NEVs were sold, up 61.7 percent year-on-year, the first time the important one-million-unit milestone was surpassed, data from the CAAM showed on Monday. CAAM forecasts NEV sales of 1.6 million units in 2019." [3] "In the first half of 2018, NEV sales doubled from the year before with a 106% increase, and saw a 68% increase in the second half of 2018, according to data from research house EV-Volumes." [4]
- "That’s thanks to China’s continuous support for NEVs, which includes government subsidies and license plate controls on diesel cars." [2] Apparently, subsidies will stop at the end of 2020, and have been "on a stepped decline since 2016. Although the new policy for 2019 has not been announced, speculation has widely circulated online that national subsidies will be reduced by 50 percent based on 2018 levels, and local ones will be canceled entirely." [3] 
-  "In January 2019, the surge in NEV sales continued in China, with a 300% increase from the previous year, which unfortunately was not echoed in the following month of February." [4] In 2019, "the NEV market in China may not be as bullish as previous years, with the Chinese government raising subsidies for new electric vehicle purchases this year from only vehicles with a range above 150km to 250km and halving subsidies for longer range NEVs. [...] Still, NEV volume in China is predicted to reach 1.8 million units by the end of 2019, 3% lower than the previous year but increasing the overall NEV market share by 55% to 6.7%." [4] 
- "Sales of electric vehicles, by contrast, are growing exponentially. CAAM said that total new energy vehicle (NEV) sales rose 85.4 per cent in March to 126,000 units. For the first quarter, total NEV sales doubled, to 299,000 units, year-on-year." [5]  I'm not sure how to integrate all of this into a model. Last year, sales were 1.26m. We have two forecasts for 2019: 1.6m and 1.8m (more recent). People seem to agree that growth will slow down significantly. I guess I'll eyeball something based on all of this info. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-autos-electric/china-targets-35-million-vehicle-sales-by-2025-nevs-to-make-up-one-fifth-idUSKBN17R086
[2] https://qz.com/1492452/car-sales-in-china-are-slowing-but-sales-of-electric-vehicles-evs-continue-to-grow/
[3] http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1136112.shtml
[4] https://thedriven.io/2019/04/12/electric-vehicle-sales-soar-in-china-as-overall-auto-market-falls/
[5] https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3005941/chinas-vehicles-sales-fell-ninth-straight-month-march

I'm lowering my forecast because China's economy may well be in trouble and this may affect consumer confidence. Dateline 3-17-2018  he accuracy of China’s official growth statistics is once again in question. Last week, at the annual “two sessions” conference, Premier Li Keqiang announced that China would reduce its 2019 target for GDP growth to between 6 and 6.5 percent—previously, it was “around 6.5 percent.” That same week, a group of Chinese economists published a paper with the Brookings Institution concluding that China’s official nominal growth rates from 2008 to 2016 were being overstated by as much as 1.7 percent.
<snip>
Data doctoring has been particularly pronounced in the northeastern industrial rust belt provinces of Heilongjiang, Jilin, and Liaoning. Liaoning, by far the most egregious data falsifier and the province where Li was formerly party secretary, was publicly denounced by the central government—a first for the party—in 2014. The National Audit Office reported that one Liaoning county inflated annual fiscal revenues by 127 percent. The province’s leadership, including the provincial chief, were made an example of and imprisoned over a separate vote-buying scandal. And now, after over a decade of adjusting local GDP data downward, the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS), China’s central statistics bureau, is assuming control of regional data collection from local bureaus starting this year.
  -- https://foreignpolicy.com/2019/03/17/chinas-economic-black-box/

Taking the past annual sales from: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_energy_vehicles_in_China#/media/File%3APEV_Registrations_China_from_2011.png
Different growth scenarios:
1) Year over year (yoy) growth rate the same as 2018/2017, gives 62% growth for 2019 compared to 2018: 2.03M vehicles
2) Growth of the yoy growth rate the same as 2018/2017, gives 71% growth for 2019 compared to 2018: 2.15M vehicles
3) 50% growth rate for 2019 compared to 2018 (all years but one since 2012 had >50% yoy growth): 1.88M vehicles
4) quadratical fit of the available data, assumption is that we are entering the exponential phase of the s-shaped curve of technology adaption (as @Emil alluded to in https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/820037) gives 35% growth for 2019 compared to 2018: 1.7M vehicles http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1136112.shtml says that subsidies are going to be phased out and end completely at the end of 2020. Costs compared to conventional vehicles are going to come down simultaneously, though. Plus, with an estimated projected 15.2M NEVs sold in China in 2030 (http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/motoring/2016-10/31/content_27226277.htm), the market seems nowhere near saturated. So I would treat scenario 4) as the lower bound. A factor that might push sales lower than 1.7M would be a recession in 2019 that also affects/includes China. However, I think if there is a recession in 2019 it will be towards the end of the year, so the decreasing effect on sales will be limited.

From the Economist supporting increased sales of EV vehicles:
Sales of passenger cars in China fell last year for the first time since 1990, puncturing the growth forecasts of the car industry. Despite a strong start to 2018, overall sales of passenger vehicles dropped by 4.1% over the 12 months, dragged down in part by a weaker yuan and the withdrawal of a tax break in late 2017. Sales of electric cars motored ahead, however, accounting for 4% of vehicle sales. The government wants this to reach 20% by 2025

Data from [1] shows 1.181 million in 2018 (assuming Dec = Nov).  We can expect future growth in the total vehicle stock to be non-linear as Chinese motorization rate (vehicle per person) rises  [2]. This non-linear growth is in line with the typical S-shaped diffusion of technology. This implies that annual sales are most likely to increase (ignoring scrappage which shouldn't change much year to year). How much could annual sales increase? Research from [2] suggests in the order of 10%. However, we also have to keep in mind that NEV share is likely to increase in line with national targets. [3] The year-on-year change from Nov 2017 to Nov 2018 is 42%. If we applied this growth to the 2018 sales, the result is 1.67 million in 2019. [1] https://www.statista.com/statistics/425458/china-monthly-new-energy-vehicle-sales-by-type/
[2] https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0361198118791361
[3] http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/motoring/2016-10/31/content_27226277.htm

Using the Statista chart, Nov 2017 to Oct 2017 is ~850k. The MoM difference in November is 42%. If we assume that as an average, we get to 1.2MM. But, there is a 20k per month ramp up in the last 6 months or so, which suggests a lot of production capacity is being developed.[1] As a comparison, the United States had a 75% increase last year. That said, the Chinese market is obviously larger and the EV market is more developed. So, let's figure 50-60% increase is most likely over 850 for the most recent 12 months, or a range of 1.275 million to 1.360 million. Going to give a slight hedge to the top and bottom choices. A slightly better than default on the 4th choice and split the difference on 2nd and 3rd from bottom. [1]https://www.statista.com/statistics/425458/china-monthly-new-energy-vehicle-sales-by-type/
